dc:description:
The relationship between COL3A1 and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, vascular type (autosomal dominant) was evaluated using the ClinGen Clinical Validity Framework as of February 25th, 2019. Variants in COL3A1 were first reported in
humans with this disease as early as 1988 (Superti-Furga et al., PMID 2834369). At least 600 unique variants are found in the Ehlers Danlos Syndrome Variant Database and ~250 more in ClinVar (Byers, 1999; PMID 20301667). This is a well-known gene-disease relationship and there is a significant amount of case-level, segregation and experimental data in the literature, therefore the maximum points for genetic and experimental evidence has been reached. The mechanism for disease is mainly gain-of-function as most cases result from missense variants leading to the substitution of a crucial glycine in the repetitive Gly-X-Y sequence of the triple helix domain, resulting in only 1 in 8 normal mature collagen homotrimers. About 5% of cases are due to haploinsufficiency and are associated with milder phenotypes (Frank et al., 2015; PMID 25758994).  This gene-disease relationship is supported by in vitro assays, expression studies,  and animal models. In summary, COL3A1 is definitively associated with autosomal dominant Ehlers Danlos Syndrome, vascular type. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time. This classification was approved by the ClinGen General GCEP on February 27, 2019 (SOP Version 6).

evidence.rdfs:label: Proband I (+1 IVS16)
evidence.detectionMethod: For initial screening for mutations, 5 single-stranded cDNA probes spanning the entire coding sequence of the human alpha1(III) chain were prepared and S1 nuclease protection experiments were performed. Overlapping PCR products were then generated from mRNA-derived cDNA from fibroblasts and sequencing was performed.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: At 33 weeks pregnant, she had hypertension, pre-eclampsia, and gestational diabetes. Premature rupture of membranes, underwent C-section, the infant died 4 hours later.

evidence.rdfs:label: P2
evidence.detectionMethod: Sequencing of entire coding region of COL3A1.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: History of easy bruising, hypermobility of small joints in hands, decreased mechanical strength of skin, atraumatic hemoperitoneum and hemorrhagic shock at 44. Tissue friability noted to be abnormal during surgery. Postoperative angiography showed numerous aneurysms of abdominal arteries. Surgical wounds caused chronic problems, with herniations of viscera.

evidence.rdfs:label: Superti-Furga 1988 Proband
evidence.detectionMethod: Comparison of the triple-elical domains of the two types of peptides produced by the patient's fibroblast (normal and shortened type III procollagen chains) and coarse Southern blot analysis of the proband's DNA predicted a large deletion in the middle of the gene. This was later characterized by PMID: 1998337.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: After age 4, fragile skin, easy bruising, and hemorrhagic blistering of the oral mucosa were noted. Habitual dislocation of the patella at age 12. Hemorrhagic pneumothrorax at 16 years. Repeated episodes of aphasia, amaurosis, and paresis of the right arm after 20. Facial features consistent with EDS IV. Systolic murmur at the left sternal margin.

evidence.rdfs:label: P1
evidence.detectionMethod: PCR and sequencing of COL3A1 coding region.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Characteristic physical findings: "pinched" nose, thin lips, lobeless ears, scant subcutaneous tissue with visible veins, multiple ecchymoses, numerous wide scars from surgeries, hypermobility of finger joints. Easy bruisability since childhood. Colonectomy at 21 for "polyposis coli", bowel tissue paper thin, several laprotomies to repair enterocutaneous fistulae complicated by bowel anastomoses and wound dehiscence. Rupture of common-hepatic-artery aneurysm at 29, resulting in large retroperitoneal hematoma. Sciatic-nerve palsy at 30 years due to spontaneous gluteal hematoma. Subarachnoid hemorrhage at 31. Patient died during surgery when the ophthalmic artery tore off the carotid artery, resulting in massive cerebral infarct.

evidence.rdfs:label: IVS24+1G>A
evidence.detectionMethod: RNA and DNA were extracted from cultured fibroblasts and cDNA was synthesized. PCR amplification of overlapping cDNA sequences- analyzed by electrophoresis for insertions/deletions or by single-strand confirmation analysis for point mutations. Abnormal fragments sequenced by dideoxy chain-termination method. Mutations confirmed by sequence analysis or restriction-enzyme digestion of genomic DNA.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Biochemically confirmed EDS Type IV. Gastrointestinal and Arterial complications reported.

evidence.dc:description: NMD does not occur.

evidence.rdfs:label: P4
evidence.detectionMethod: Direct sequencing of exons 45-52, including the region that encodes the carboxyl-terminus.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: History of easy bruising. Evaluated for anemia at 45 years, abdominal CT revealed aneurysm of the left common iliac artery. Three months later a new infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm and dissection extending from the infrarenal aorta to the left common iliac artery.

evidence.rdfs:label: P3
evidence.detectionMethod: Sequenced entire coding region of COL3A1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Soft, velvety, translucent skin, atrophic scars on lower extremities. Multiple infarcts in left kidney, dissection of left renal artery, multiple dissections involving splenic and hepatic branches of the celiac artery and both renal arteries. Occlusion of the gastroduodenal artery. Became critically ill with cardiac and adrenal insufficiency and acute respiratory failure.

evidence.rdfs:label: Proband III (+1 IVS42)
evidence.detectionMethod: For initial screening for mutations, 5 single-stranded cDNA probes spanning the entire coding sequence of the human alpha1(III) chain were prepared and S1 nuclease protection experiments were performed. Overlapping PCR products were then generated from mRNA-derived cDNA from fibroblasts and sequencing was performed.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Died from ruptured dissecting aortic aneurysm at 22 years. Previous surgical repair for congenital hip dislocations and torn knee ligament.

evidence.rdfs:label: Cortini 2016 Proband
evidence.detectionMethod: Next-Generation sequencing. 9 genes were included in the HaloPlex Target Enrichment panel (ADAMTS2, B4GALT7, CHST14, COL3A1, COL5A1, COL5A2, PLOD1, PLOD3, TNXB).
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: "Typical symptoms of vEDS." Referred an ischemic perforation of her sigmoid-rectum with stercoral peritonitis.

evidence.dc:description: This substitution affects the glycine residue in a Gly-X-Y motif in the triple helical region of COL3A1. There is a transgenic mouse model that supports its pathogenicity.

evidence.rdfs:label: G16S
evidence.detectionMethod: RNA and DNA were extracted from cultured fibroblasts and cDNA was synthesized. PCR amplification of overlapping cDNA sequences- analyzed by electrophoresis for insertions/deletions or by single-strand confirmation analysis for point mutations. Abnormal fragments sequenced by dideoxy chain-termination method. Mutations confirmed by sequence analysis or restriction-enzyme digestion of genomic DNA.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Index patients were biochemically confirmed EDS Type IV (cultured fibroblasts from patients synthesized abnormal type III procollagen molecules). Both bowel and arterial complications were indicated for this proband.

evidence.dc:description: No functional evidence.

evidence.rdfs:label: Gly499Asp
evidence.detectionMethod: RNA and DNA were extracted from cultured fibroblasts and cDNA was synthesized. PCR amplification of overlapping cDNA sequences- analyzed by electrophoresis for insertions/deletions or by single-strand confirmation analysis for point mutations. Abnormal fragments sequenced by dideoxy chain-termination method. Mutations confirmed by sequence analysis or restriction-enzyme digestion of genomic DNA.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Biochemically confirmed EDS Type IV. Gastrointestinal and arterial complications reported.

evidence.dc:description: No functional evidence.

evidence.rdfs:label: III.3
evidence.detectionMethod: Targeted Next-Gen sequencing of 17 genes involved in vascular fragility (ACTA2, CBS, COL3A1, COL5A1, COL5A2, ELN, FBN1, MYH11, MYLK, SLC2A10, SMAD3, TGFB2, TGFB3, TGFBR1, TGFBR) was performed on the proband. Family members further underwent DNA analysis to identify the COL3A1 variant.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Dissection of right common iliac artery.

evidence.dc:description: No functional evidence.

evidence.rdfs:label: Gly385Glu
evidence.detectionMethod: RNA and DNA were extracted from cultured fibroblasts and cDNA was synthesized. PCR amplification of overlapping cDNA sequences- analyzed by electrophoresis for insertions/deletions or by single-strand confirmation analysis for point mutations. Abnormal fragments sequenced by dideoxy chain-termination method. Mutations confirmed by sequence analysis or restriction-enzyme digestion of genomic DNA.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Biochemically confirmed EDS Type IV. Gastrointestinal and arterial complications reported.

evidence.dc:description: Variant occurs in one of the triple helical region in which variants are known to cause EDS type IV and has been found in multiple unrelated individuals. No variant-level evidence.

evidence.rdfs:label: Gly415Ser
evidence.detectionMethod: RNA and DNA were extracted from cultured fibroblasts and cDNA was synthesized. PCR amplification of overlapping cDNA sequences- analyzed by electrophoresis for insertions/deletions or by single-strand confirmation analysis for point mutations. Abnormal fragments sequenced by dideoxy chain-termination method. Mutations confirmed by sequence analysis or restriction-enzyme digestion of genomic DNA.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Biochemically confirmed EDS Type IV. Arterial complications reported.

evidence.dc:description: Glycine residues within the Gly-Xaa-Yaa repeats of the triple helix domain are required for the structure and stability of fibrillar collagens. No functional evidence.

evidence.rdfs:label: Gly373Arg
evidence.detectionMethod: RNA and DNA were extracted from cultured fibroblasts and cDNA was synthesized. PCR amplification of overlapping cDNA sequences- analyzed by electrophoresis for insertions/deletions or by single-strand confirmation analysis for point mutations. Abnormal fragments sequenced by dideoxy chain-termination method. Mutations confirmed by sequence analysis or restriction-enzyme digestion of genomic DNA.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Biochemically confirmed EDS Type IV. Gastrointestinal and arterial complications reported.

evidence.dc:description: No functional evidence.

evidence.rdfs:label: Kashizaki 2013 Proband
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Hysterectomy at 26 years 1 month after giving birth due to an intractable uterine hemorrhage. Stripping of varicose veins of lower extremities at 49 years. Diagnosed with arteriovenous fistulae of her lower extremities at 62 years. History of skin ulcers. Abnormal CT showed saccular and fusiform aneurysms in celiac artery, splenic artery, superior mesenteric artery, right and left renal arteries, and right and left common iliac arteries.

evidence.rdfs:label: Baas 2016 EDS Family
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Affected family members had a history of vascular complications.

evidence.dc:description: The mouse phenotypes are consistent with the human disease and the mechanism (dominant negative) is the same.

Patients with vEDS are susceptible to rupture of arteries, bowel, and uterus. Most cases are caused by a missense variant leading to the substitution of a critical glycine in the repetitive Gly-Xaa-Yaa sequence of the collagen triple helix domain, leading to a dominant negative effect: only 1 in 8 collagen homotrimers are normal. Transgenic mice carrying p.Gly182Ser (human p.Gly183Ser) variant show signs of vascular and dermal fragility with aberrant collagen fibrils in the aorta and dermis.
evidence.rdfs:label: Transgenic Mouse Model

evidence.dc:description: Acute aortic rupture shown in the mutant mouse line is consistent with EDS Type IV  patients with haploinsufficiency who also exhibit vascular complications. Although the heterozygous mice from the Liu 1997 paper did not show this phenotype, recent studies have demonstrated that the mice do have reduced levels of aortic collagen and reduced aortic wall strength. Histologically, they have minor aortic lesions that appear between 2 and 14 months (PMID: 20587693). The differences between these two studies may be due to genetic background and modifiers.

Gene-targeting experiment resulted in spontaneous 185 kb deletion of Col3a1 including the promoter region and exons 1-39. Q-PCR was used to quantify DNA within the deleted region and carriers were identified by a 50% reduction of product compared to wild type litter mates. Cause of death in all cases was acute aortic dissection with rupture of the ascending or descending thoracic aorta.  Medial collagen content in thoracic aortas from mutant mice was lower than wild type. TEM analysis revealed clear aortic abnormalities in mutant mice (elastic lamellae showed reduced electron density, variable width, and disrupted architecture).
evidence.rdfs:label: Smith 2011 Haploinsufficient Mouse Model

evidence.dc:description: Medial collagen content in thoracic aortas from mutant mice was lower than wild type. TEM analysis revealed clear aortic abnormalities in mutant mice (elastic lamellae showed reduced electron density, variable width, and disrupted architecture). Molecular mechanism is not the same so points were reduced.

Type III collagen is critical for fibrillogenesis and is an essential component of fibrils in tissues such as the aorta but is also important in regulating type I collagen fibrils. The phenotype of col3a1 null mice is similar to clinical manifestations of EDS Type IV, in which patients often experience blood vessel or intestinal rupture, leading to death. Although the heterozygous mice did not show this phenotype, recent studies have demonstrated that the mice do have reduced levels of aortic collagen and reduced aortic wall strength. Histologically, they have minor aortic lesions that appear between 2 and 14 months (PMID: 20587693).
evidence.rdfs:label: Col3a1 Null Mouse Model

evidence.dc:description: Evidence of a dominant negative effect.

Primary human skin fibroblast cultures were obtained from skin biopsies of a patient with a p.G252V mutation and a control individual. Also from a patient with a different glycine substitution (p.G501A) and a haploinsufficient patient (p.Q857X). Patients with EDS Type IV are unable to form well-organized extracellular matrices. In the p.G252V patient cells, labeling with antibodies against collagen types I and III showed disorganized bundles of collagen fibrils. They identified a single siRNA that was able to knockdown the mutant COL3A1 mRNA in the p.G252V patient without affecting the wild type COL3A1. After treatment with the siRNA, the morphology of the extracellular matrix more closely resembled the healthy control fibroblasts.
evidence.rdfs:label: siRNA rescue

evidence.dc:description: Primary human skin fibroblast cultures were obtained from skin biopsies of a patient with a p.G252V mutation and a control individual. Also from a patient with a different glycine substitution (p.G501A) and a haploinsufficient patient (p.Q857X). Patients with EDS Type IV are unable to form well-organized extracellular matrices. In the p.G252V patient cells, labeling with antibodies against collagen types I and III showed disorganized bundles of collagen fibrils. They identified a single siRNA that was able to knockdown the mutant COL3A1 mRNA in the p.G252V patient without affecting the wild type COL3A1. After treatment with the siRNA, the morphology of the extracellular matrix more closely resembled the healthy control fibroblasts.
evidence.rdfs:label: siRNA

evidence.dc:description: Review: Type III collagen, which is a homotrimer of 3 alpha1(III) chains encoded by COL3A1, is a classic fibril-forming collagen that assembles into highly organized aggregates. Type III collagen is found in skin, vessel wall, and reticular fibers of most tissues.  Phenotypes with EDS type IV include arterial, intestinal and/or uterine fragility, thin/translucent skin, easy bruising, vascular dissection or rupture, gastrointestinal perforation or organ rupture .
evidence.rdfs:label: Type III Collagen

evidence.dc:description: Expression in connective tissue is consistent with disease phenotype.

Skin biopsies from controls and EDS Type IV patient were taken to culture fibroblasts. Northern blot analysis was performed on mutant and control fibroblasts, showing an abundance of type III collagen. Differences in the expression of normal type III collagen is an established method of diagnosing EDS Type IV.
evidence.rdfs:label: Superti-Furga 1988 Expression
